subject: Psychology
title: Constructed Emotion Theory
description: A short lesson to help you apply Constructed Emotion Theory.

hook.text: Lisa Feldman Barrett says emotions aren't hardwired reactions. Your brain constructs them on the fly.

buildup.text: Her theory of constructed emotion argues the brain uses past experience, context, and concepts to build feelings.

discovery.text: There's no single brain circuit for anger or fear. Instead, emotions emerge from general-purpose networks.

twist.text: This means people with richer emotional vocabularies literally experience more nuanced emotions.

climax.text: If emotions are constructed, they're also shapeable. You can learn to build your emotional experiences differently.

punchline.text: Your brain doesn't have emotions. It makes them.

quiz.question: What does constructed emotion theory propose?
options: The brain builds emotions from experience and context
Only six emotions exist in all humans
